Digital signal processing: mathematical manipulation of an information signal
Transmission (telecommunications): process of sending and propagating a signal
Computer science: study of computation

Information technology management: the discipline whereby all of the information technology resources of a firm are managed in accordance with its needs and priorities

Tiltmeter: instrument designed to measure very small changes from the vertical level

Galvanometer: instrument to measure electric current

Theodolite: surveying instrument that measures azimuth and elevation between points

Measuring instrument: device for measuring a physical quantity

CTD: oceanography instrument used to measure the conductivity, temperature, and pressure of seawater

SODAR: meteorological instrumentation

Biomass burning: (no longer living) biological material used as a renewable energy source

Biotechnology: use of living systems and organisms to develop or make useful products
Pharmaceutical industry: develops, produces, and markets drugs or pharmaceuticals licensed for use as medications
Supramolecular chemistry: domain of chemistry beyond that of molecules that focuses on the chemical systems made up of a discrete number of assembled molecular subunits or components
Food chemistry: study of chemical processes and interactions of all biological and non-biological components of foods
Material chemistry: interdisciplinary field which deals with the discovery and design of new materials; primarily concerned with the physical and chemical properties of solids
Metallurgy: domain of materials science that studies the physical and chemical behavior of metals
Coating: any substance spread over a surface
Nanotechnology: field of applied science whose theme is the control of matter on atomic and (supra)molecular scale

Chemical engineering: branch of science that applies physical sciences and life sciences together with applied mathematics and economics to produce, transform, transport, and properly use chemicals, materials and energy
Environmental science: interdisciplinary field that studies human interaction with the environment
Material handling: sub-discipline of mechanical engineering
Machine tool: machine for shaping or machining metal, has means for constraining the workpiece and provides a guided tool movement
Diesel engine: internal combustion engine with quality rotational frequency governing, internal mixture formation, lean air-fuel-ratio, diffusion flame and compression ignition
Internal combustion engine: engine in which the combustion of a fuel occurs with an oxidizer in a combustion chamber
Starter: motor used to start an internal combustion engine
Gas turbines: type of internal combustion engine
Fuel injection: aspect of an internal combustion engine
Spark plug: device that generates sparks in internal combustion engines
Distributor: device in the ignition system of an internal combustion engine
Gas engine: internal combustion engine powered by natural gas
Motor oil: lubricant used for lubrication of internal combustion engines
Rotary engine: internal combustion engine with cylinders rotating around a stationary crankshaft
Textile: material produced by twining, weaving, felting, knotting, or otherwise processing natural or synthetic fibers
Paper machine: machine used to manufacture paper products

Differential (mechanical device): type of simple planetary gear train
Turbine: rotary mechanical device that extracts energy from a fluid flow
Flywheel: mechanical device specifically designed to efficiently store rotational energy (kinetic energy), which is proportional to the square of its rotational speed and its mass
Gas compressor: mechanical device that increases the pressure of a gas by reducing its volume
Propulsor: mechanical device that gives propulsion. The word is commonly used in the marine vernacular, and implies a mechanical assembly that is more complicated than a propeller
Superconducting electric machine: type of electromechanical device
Intercooler: specific type of mechanical device used to cool liquid or gas
Pulverizer: mechanical device
Ratchet: mechanical device that allows continuous linear or rotary motion in only one direction
Intra-aortic balloon pump: mechanical device that increases myocardial oxygen perfusion while at the same time increasing cardiac outpu
Buckle: mechanical device for fastening two loose ends
Articulator: mechanical device used in dentistry
Intra-Aortic Balloon Pumping: mechanical device that increases myocardial oxygen perfusion while at the same time increasing cardiac outpu
Braking system: mechanical device that inhibits motion
Transport engineering: academic discipline and occupational field
Furniture industry: movable objects used to equip households, offices, or shops for purposes such as storage, seating, sleeping
Consumables: good with short durability
Civil engineering: engineering discipline specializing in design, construction and maintenance of the built environment
Renewable energy: energy that is collected from renewable resources
